title: Understanding the spontaneity condition
text:
For a chemical reaction to be spontaneous, the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) must be less than zero. This can be expressed with the formula:

ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - TΔS

Using this equation, calculate the temperature range for which this reaction becomes spontaneous.

title: Plugging values into the Gibbs equation
text:
Using the equation ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - TΔS, we can plug in the values provided:

ΔG $$=$$ $$92.22$$ - T × $$\left(- rac{198.5}{1000}ight)$$

Convert the change in entropy (ΔS) from $$ rac{J}{mol·K}$$ to $$ rac{kJ}{mol·K}$$, since ΔH is given in $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$.

title: Finding when ΔG $$=$$ $$0$$
text: To find the temperature at which the reaction becomes spontaneous, set ΔG $$=$$ $$0$$ in the Gibbs equation:\n\n$$0$$ $$=$$ ΔH - TΔS

title: Solving for the temperature
text:
Now that you know $$ΔG=0$$ for spontaneity and have the equations:

$$0$$ $$=$$ $$92.22$$ - T × $$(-0.1985)$$

Solve this equation for T.

title: Interpreting the results
text: Given that $$T=464.4$$ K is the temperature where $$ΔG=0$$, analyze if there are temperatures below or above where the reaction is spontaneous.

hintAnswer: Reaction is not spontaneous at any temperature.
title: Determine spontaneity range
text: Since this is an endothermic reaction (ΔH > 0) and ΔS < $$0$$, evaluate ΔG to see if it becomes negative at specific temperature ranges.
choices: Reaction is not spontaneous at any temperature.
